title: Royal Edinburgh; Her Saints, Kings, Prophets and Poets
author: Oliphant, Mrs. (Margaret)
snippet: These visitors were the famous Andrew Melville, Principal of the NewCollege at St. Andrews, a scholar almost as distinguished as himself,who had at an earlier period been Buchanan's pupil, and who had acquiredhis great knowledge in the same way, in the famous schools of thecontinent; James Melville, his nephew, minister of Kilrenny on theshores of Fife; and Thomas Buchanan, the cousin of the dying historian.

title: A selection from the correspondence of the late Thomas Chalmers /
author: Chalmers, Thomas
snippet: They were powerfully awakened wheh I stood besore the tomb of your aunt in the church-yard of Kilrenny,and have just now been revived with ten-sold force by theperusal of certain documents which have been kindly put intomy hands, and from which I have gathered particulars newto myself, but most deeply affecting, relative to the death ofMrs. Brown, and to that of your dear mother, for whom I havecherished, during the long period of fifty-five years, such regards and remembrances as can never be effaced.

title: A selection from the correspondence of the late Thomas Chalmers /
author: Chalmers, Thomas
snippet: My very dear Friend — I must delay no longer to acknowledge your very welcome letter with the packet I received from your daughters, and for the contents of which Ihave the greatest value, both the testimony to one whom Inever can forget or think of without eraotion, and the letterfrom Kilrenny, with your own precious notes respecting thelast illness of her who obviously died in the triumphs of thefaith.

author: Chalmers, Thomas
snippet: ,When in Kilrenny church-yard, I was so engrossed withthe tablet appropriated to dear Anne, that I have carriedaway an imperfect remembrance of that which was raisedfor Mr. Brown.

title: A selection from the correspondence of the late Thomas Chalmers /
author: Chalmers, Thomas
snippet: The monuraent to Anne Rankine and herinfant child in Kilrenny church-yard is a very interesting object : it is upon the north wall, a little way from GeneralScott's large mausoleum.

title: A selection from the correspondence of the late Thomas Chalmers /
author: Chalmers, Thomas
snippet: I preached in the afternoon at Kilrenny, and stayedall evening and night in the manse — interesting from thepresence of Maiy Forrester, who, in spite of her " twa bairns,"is the sarae giggler as ever.

title: A selection from the correspondence of the late Thomas Chalmers /
author: Chalmers, Thomas
snippet: On the Sunday morning we walked in a family groupfrom Barnsmuir to Kilrenny — a beautiful day, and most interesting road, all the turns and objeots of which you wellknow.

title: A selection from the correspondence of the late Thomas Chalmers /
author: Chalmers, Thomas
snippet: I got down to dinner, and met acompany of coast-siders — Mr. Brown, of Kilrenny, Mr. andMrs. Wilson, of Anster, Hall Pringle and his sister, from Largo, &c. I stopped at Barnsmuir all night.

title: A selection from the correspondence of the late Thomas Chalmers /
author: Chalmers, Thomas
snippet: On the one occasion I preached at Crail, and on the other atKilrenny.

title: A selection from the correspondence of the late Thomas Chalmers /
author: Chalmers, Thomas
snippet: I felt great interest in being with Mrs. Brown(Mary Forrester) at Kilrenny, where her father was rainister.

title: A selection from the correspondence of the late Thomas Chalmers /
author: Chalmers, Thomas
snippet: I went down to Anster onthe Saturday— ^walked to Kilrenny after breakfast — preachedthere in the afternoon — dined with Mr. Brown, and walkedin the evening to Barnsmuir with Mr. Fortune.

title: A selection from the correspondence of the late Thomas Chalmers /
author: Chalmers, Thomas
snippet: My object in going down was to preach at Kilrenny, whichI did to a very full audience.

title: A selection from the correspondence of the late Thomas Chalmers /
author: Chalmers, Thomas
snippet: Third-part avenue,Clishmacclash, &c., &c. I breakfasted in Kilrenny Manse,and was most cordially entertained by Mary Forrester, whoselittle son of nine weeks old formed an interesting novelty inthe group.
